item.title: ECB Sets Deadline for Cyprus Deal
item.description: The ECB ramped up pressure on Cyprus to seal a bailout pact with the EU and the IMF by Monday, making further funding for the island's ailing banks contingent on a deal.

item.title: Riots in Myanmar Stir Fears of Growing Religious Unrest
item.description: More than a thousand police were deployed to quell sectarian clashes that left at least five people dead and a mosque in ashes, raising concerns of religious violence spreading in the country.

item.title: Canadian Budget Limits Spending Growth
item.description: The Canadian government stuck to its target of a balanced budget in 2015, in a spending plan that underscores Canada's position as one of the few developed nations not piling on debt at a rapid pace—even as the government announced measures to counter growing economic headwinds.

item.title: Bangladesh Unrest Risks Derailing Its Textile Boon
item.description: Troubles in Bangladesh are beginning to spoil its reputation among foreign companies, highlighting risks to investors looking for new manufacturing bases cheaper than China.

item.title: Cyprus Court Convicts Hezbollah Member
item.description: A Cypriot court convicted a 24-year-old member of Hezbollah on charges he plotted terror attacks against Jews last summer on the Mediterranean island, a decision that could raise pressure on the European Union to blacklist the Lebanon-based group.

item.title: U.N. Body Condemns Sri Lanka
item.description: A United Nations human-rights body harshly criticized Sri Lanka for failing to heal the wounds of a civil war that ended four years ago and for continued rights violations.

item.title: U.N. Watchdog to Probe North Korea Rights Abuse
item.description: The U.N.'s Human Rights Council approved a framework to step up investigations into rights abuses in North Korea, providing more fuel to international efforts to pressure Pyongyang as it expands its weapons programs.

item.title: Date Set for Scottish Independence Poll
item.description: People in Scotland will vote on Sept. 18, 2014, on whether to stay in the U.K. or become an independent country, setting the stage for 18 months of intense campaigning.

item.title: New Archbishop of Canterbury Enthroned
item.description: The new archbishop of Canterbury was formally enthroned—and questions about the Church of England's opposition to same-sex marriage greeted his promotion.

item.title: U.K. Utility SSE to Cut Capacity
item.description: The company says government policy has made operating many power plants uneconomic, while analysts see a capacity shortage looming.

item.title: Europe Data Fuel Worries
item.description: A sharp fall in euro-zone business activity in March cemented fears the bloc's economy has shrunk in the first quarter of the year.

item.title: Mali Militants Attack Airport
item.description: Islamist militants attacked the airport in Mali's desert city of Timbuktu, challenging a claim by France's President François Hollande that the country would soon recover its territorial integrity.

item.title: India Parliament Clears Tough Rape Law
item.description: India's Parliament approved a bill that aims to strengthen the country's law on sexual assaults against women with stringent punishments for offences like rape, stalking, voyeurism and acid attacks.

item.title: Bomb Strikes Pakistani Refugee Camp
item.description: A car packed with explosives blew up inside a refugee camp in northwestern Pakistan, killing 13 and wounding 25.

item.title: Former 200-Meter Record Holder Mennea Dies
item.description: Pietro Mennea, an Olympic sprint champion from Italy who held the world record in the 200 meters for 17 years, has died in Rome.

item.title: Sanctions Slash Iranian Crude Capacity Near 20%
item.description: Iran's crude production capacity is down almost 20% due to strict sanctions imposed by western governments on the nation, according to figures published by the International Energy Agency.

item.title: Japan's Trade Deficit Narrows
item.description: Japan's merchandise trade deficit in February narrowed from its record pace in the previous month, amid hopes that a weaker yen and a global economic recovery will revive Japan's long-suffering export industries.

item.title: India Agency Probes Former Government Ally
item.description: India's federal investigation agency raided the home of a leader of a party that pulled out of India's governing coalition this week, sparking accusations from the party of political interference in the process.

item.title: China Manufacturing Activity Expands
item.description: A preliminary gauge of manufacturing activity in China sped up in March, suggesting steady momentum in the country's economy despite recent caution.

item.title: Actor Sanjay Dutt Sentenced to Prison
item.description: India's top court sentenced Bollywood actor Sanjay Dutt to five years in jail for the illegal possession of arms in a case linked to a 1993 bombing that killed 257 people in Mumbai.

item.title: New BOJ Chief Renews Easing Pledge
item.description: The Bank of Japan's new governor renewed his pledge to expand monetary easing, saying that it is "indispensable" to increase the amount of assets the central bank buys from the market.

item.title: Crisis Won't Hurt Euro Zone---Unless Cyprus Leaves
item.description: Eight months after Cyprus requested a financial rescue, bleary-eyed finance ministers cobbled together a package early Saturday that has become so contentious that it risks the country's euro-zone membership.

item.title: Merkel's Hard Line Cheers Germany
item.description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's hard line on European bailouts has sparked anger in Cyprus but boosted her standing at home.

item.title: Russians Rethink Go-To Banking Center
item.description: Russians, who have helped build Cyprus's financial sector by pouring billions of dollars into the island's banks, are having second thoughts after the country considered a plan to tax account-holders' deposits.

item.title: Diana's Million-Dollar Wardrobe
item.description: Kerry Taylor Auctions expects to raise more than £800,000 pounds ($1.2 million) with the sale of 10 dresses belonging to Britain's late Princess Diana, which are up for auction Tuesday.

item.title: Wu Led Village to Become China's Richest
item.description: Wu Renbao, who used "capitalism with Chinese characteristics" to turn a farm community into what is now known in China as the country's richest village, died of lung cancer.

item.title: Belgian Train Museum Had a Hard Time Getting on Track
item.description: The latest problem for this train-mad country: too many historic steam engines.

item.title: Photos of the Day: March 21
item.description: In today's pictures, Hindus celebrate a festival, a new image from space bolsters the big-bang theory and the idea of an older universe, a hare cowers in Germany, and more.

item.title: Printing the Future
item.description: Three-dimensional printers, which gradually layer materials to form shapes, are making rapid progress in manufacturing, medicine—and Fashion Week.

item.title: Separatist Regions
item.description: One unexpected consequence of the euro-zone crisis has been the re-emergence of separatist movements around Europe. Jonathan House, Frances Robinson and Ainsley Thomson profile some of the regions across the Continent where the clamor for secession is reaching fever pitch.

item.title: Spring Is Here
item.description: Around the Northern Hemisphere, people are marking the end of winter with gatherings, rituals and celebrations.

item.title: Beijing's Spring Snowfall
item.description: Beijing residents woke up Wednesday, the first official day of spring in the Chinese traditional calendar, to a city blanketed in white after an overnight snow storm.
